entries.content: Look, if you fancy setting aside 10 minutes for a brief chat when convenient, let me know. Otherwise, I'd understand if I never hear from you again.
entries.notes: Used in email follow-up after a referral introduction, handles potential ghosting or disinterest softly by giving them an easy out.

entries.content: When a prospect says they don't recognize the problems, use a soft, push-away probe to elicit a response.
entries.notes: Avoids direct pressure, encourages them to reveal their underlying reason for disinterest.

entries.content: But I get the feeling you're gonna tell me you wouldn't believe me anyway, are you?
entries.notes: Example of a soft, push-away probe used when a prospect claims not to have the problems discussed.

entries.content: After a prospect responds to a soft probe (like 'you wouldn't believe me, would you?'), ask 'Can I ask why?' to understand their reasoning.
entries.notes: Directly probes the source of their disbelief or disinterest.

entries.content: Don't get upset or angry when a prospect says 'no' or 'not interested'. Recognize it may mean the conversation won't go anywhere *now*.
entries.notes: Helps maintain composure and allows for low-pressure follow-up attempts.

entries.content: Avoid asking high-pressure questions like 'Would that interest you?' as it pulls the prospect towards you and is easily dismissed.
entries.notes: Contrasts with the soft, push-away probing technique.

entries.content: As you're reading this, you're probably thinking none of this applies to you, in which case delete this message. However, if you thought to yourself no, these resonate...
entries.notes: Example of a soft, push-away probe used in email prospecting.

focus_area: Handling "Not Interested": Probe softly, diagnose if disinterest or timing
